channel.title: free range statistics
channel.description: I write about applications of data and analytical techniques like statistical modelling and simulation to real-world situations. I show how to access and use data, and provide examples of analytical products and the code that produced them.

item.title: A more systematic look at suppressed data
item.description: A more systematic comparison of different ways of dealing with cells in a cross tab that have been supressed for confidentiality. For the particular model tested here, the best thing to do is the simple method of replacing all suppressed cells with 5; this works even better than using the original unsuppressed data which is very unstable when many cell counts are near zero.

item.title: Suppressed data (left-censored counts)
item.description: I experiment with some different ways of handling counts in tables that have been suppressed for confidentiality, and come up in favour of multiple imputation. The mice R package helpfully lets you define your own imputation algorithm.

item.title: Simulating simple dice games
item.description: I play around with simulating some dice games.

item.title: Understanding the limitations of group-level inequality data
item.description: Cross-sectional country-level data will show a relationship between income inequality and life expectancy even if inequality itself has no direct impact on life exectancy; so long as there is changing marginal impact of individual income on individual life space (as of course there is).

item.title: Sri Lanka visitor arrivals
item.description: Sri Lanka has a rapidly growing tourism industry, two international tourism seasons, and seasonality patterns in arrivals that vary according to country of origin.

item.title: Rents in Melbourne
item.description: Rents in Melbourne have on average grown fastest in suburbs that were the cheapest in 2000; at least for two and three bedroom flats and for two bedroom houses. Also, scatterplots are awesome.

item.title: Estimating relative risk in a simulated complex survey
item.description: Simulating complex survey data in order to fit slightly mis-specified relative risk models, we find that confidence intervals' coverage is pretty much as advertised if we use appropriate methods that adjust for the complex survey data, but under-perform if the data is treated naively as coming from a simple random sample.

item.title: Relative risk ratios and odds ratios
item.description: Explanation and demonstration with simulated data of the difference between relative risk ratios and odds ratios, and how to extract them from a generalized linear model.

item.title: Time series intervention analysis with fuel prices
item.description: I look into whether the regional fuel tax in Auckland has led to changes in fuel prices in other regions of New Zealand.

item.title: Leading indicators of economic growth
item.description: A demo of a favourite combination of multiple imputation, bootstrap and elastic net regularization. I look at what are good leading indicators, with reliable data available, of New Zealand's economic growth. The results turn out to be last quarter's economic growth; food prices; visitor arrivals; car registrations; business confidence; and electronic card transactions.
